title: Research in-process filesystem access (jco, Wasmer SDK, custom imports)
description:
Evaluate approaches to replace sidecar subprocess with in-process filesystem access.

## Approaches to evaluate

### 1. jco + WASI 0.2 Component Model (primary)
- Jco 1.0 released, production-ready (Bytecode Alliance)
- WASI 0.2 with real filesystem via preview2-shim
- Node.js lacks native WASI P2, so jco is the practical JS path
- Prototype: compile taglib_wasi.wasm as WASI component, transpile with jco
- Test filesystem access in Node.js and Deno

### 2. Wasmer @wasmer/sdk with WASIX (alternative)
- Can mount real host directories (unlike @wasmer/wasi which only has MemFS)
- Previous attempt used wrong package (@wasmer/wasi) — @wasmer/sdk is the correct one
- Note: security concerns around sandbox bypass (GHSA-55f3-3qvg-8pv5)

### 3. Custom host functions (simplest)
- Skip WASI filesystem entirely
- Expose read_file(path)/write_file(path, bytes) as Wasm imports
- Essentially an in-process version of what sidecar does
- Lowest complexity, most control, but non-standard

## Success criteria
- In-process (no subprocess)
- Real filesystem access (not MemFS)
- Works in Node.js and Deno
- Latency competitive with sidecar approach
close_reason: Implemented in-process WASI host with real filesystem syscalls. loadWasiHost() provides path-based and buffer-based access.
